comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Wajahat Mahmood: Thank you for your interest in this image as possibly the tomb of Ottoman architect Sinan (d. 1588). I found the below photographs of Sinan's tomb in the Süleymaniye complex, Istanbul (ca. 1980) at the Archnet: Islamic Architecture Community digital library. The structures do not resemble the photochrom image: archnet.org/library/images/one-image.jsp?location_id=4395... archnet.org/library/images/one-image.jsp?location_id=4395... However, according to the book The age of Sinan: Architectural culture in the Ottoman Empire (Gülru Necipoğlu, 2005, p. 150), Sinan endowed a masjid (mosque) and school with a public fountain in Yenibahçe (now Fatih), Istanbul. The original masjid burned in 1918 and was restored in 1976. The photographs of the current building, show windows resembling the windows in the building in the above image, but differ in other ways: www.sinanasaygi.org/en/eserler.asp?action=eserDetay&I... It would be exciting if we could confirm that the photochrom image shows Sinan’s masjid before the fire of 1918. What do you think? Thanks for encouraging us to dig deeper!

comment.author: 10069721@N00
comment._content: It is the part of Koca Sinan Pasha Complex, sebil (fountain) and tomb.

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: ~caner:  Thank you for posting the picture of the Koca Sinan Pasha Complex. It confirms that the print in the P&P collection is this group of buildings at an earlier time. We will include the new information in the record when we update. We greatly appreciate your help!
